poem:
Adrift

In the expanse—  
a solitary ring  
bears dreams afloat;  
the blue horizon,  
indifferent eyes.  
Hope, a fragile lifeline,  
flutters on waves;  
passing vessels,  
silent phantoms.  
Fear clings, salted—  
yet beneath,  
a heartbeat whispers:  
not yet, not yet.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I was terrified of dying’: how one man survived 40 hours adrift in the sea For more than 40 hours he floated in the Mediterranean, buoyed only by an inflatable ring and flippers. Gripped by fear and disheartened by the handful of vessels that had passed by him, Rafie Nadi, 23, was kept from slipping under by a jumble of hopes. Five years earlier, he had set off from Egypt to help provide for his". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
